div.head: The Preface to the READER.
div.p:
THat State which would pre≈øerve it ≈øelf from Ruine and De≈øtruction is ever to keep its Inhabitants pure and clean from Vice and Debauchery, and their Laws from violation and corruption, as the fir≈øt is a way or means to engage a con≈øcientious obedience and ob≈øervation of the ju≈øt and upright Law of God; ≈øo the ≈øecond by rea≈øon of their due execution are the Sinews or Sanctures that bind the Inhabitants of ≈øuch State in a perpetual Bond of Safety and Tranquility; and its certainly true where either of the≈øe are violated or neglected, the ruin of that State is near at hand. There's no better way to incline the Subjects of any State to Morality and Vertile, then that tho≈øe that ≈øit at the Helme, or have the Government thereof, ≈øhould hold forth clear Examples and Patterns of Piety and Iu≈øtice in their Lives and Actions; Regis ad exemplum totus componitur orbis, ≈øaith the Poet, The whole World immitate the Example of their King. And as the Divine Hi≈øtorian Jo≈øephus ob≈øerves in his Eccle≈øia≈øtical Hi≈øtory, Fol. 209. But (≈øaith he) mortal men mo≈øt u≈øually are corrupted by the untoward Flatteries of wavering 2 Chron. 13. 18, 19, 20. fortune, as appeareth by King Reoboam, ≈øeeing his Kingdom thus increa≈øed, he bent him≈øelf to all unju≈øt and impious Actions, and contemned the Service of God; the People al≈øo conformed them≈øelves to his Impieties; for the Life of the Subjects is oftentimes perverted by rea≈øon of the corrupt and di≈ø≈øolute Life of their Princes; and tho≈øe that are Inferiours beholding the Riot of their Superiours, will ea≈øily be withdrawn from all Mode≈øty, and follow tho≈øe Vices they profe≈øs, as if they had been their profe≈ø≈øed Vertues: For ≈øhould they do the contrary, they ≈øhould ≈øeem to di≈øanul and mi≈ølike the Actions of their Princes‚ÄîThe Subjects addicted them≈øelves to Impiety, and all Errors; for they would not make profe≈ø≈øion of hone≈øty, for fear they ≈øhould ≈øeem to ≈øtuddy the means to be offen≈øive unto the King. From this lively Patern, or Repre≈øentative of our
pre≈øent Times, or State, we mu≈øt wi≈øh that Princes in this Age would con≈øider, and put in practice that Golden Rule of Demo≈øthenes, Bene gubernare, recte W. H's Epi≈øtle in his Tran≈ølation of Myrror of Ju≈øtice. judicare, ju≈øte facere; to Govern well, judge rightly, and do ju≈øtly, ≈øo ≈øhould their Kingdoms flouri≈øh, and they them≈øelves be in high e≈øtimation in the eyes of their People.

And next the Princes curious eye over his own per≈øonal actions, a due heed care and regard is to be had to his Repre≈øentatives in his Courts of Iu≈øtice; viz. tho≈øe Iu≈øtices whom he con≈øtitutes by his Commi≈ø≈øion (to hear and determine betwixt him and his People) that they be ≈øuch who by their due Admini≈øtration and faithfull di≈øpen≈øing-of the Laws, Ju≈øtice and Right may be done to all men without re≈øpect of Per≈øons.

But as Vice and Debauchery have devoured and eaten up the Nations practice of Religion, ≈øcarce leaving us the out≈øide Shell of profe≈ø≈øion; ≈øo hath the corruption of our Laws, and the violation thereof turned back tho≈øe whol≈øom Streams of Iu≈øtice which ≈øhould naturally ≈ølow from the u≈øe of them.

And that thou (Reader) may≈øt ≈øee that thy ≈øelf art one, who is in danger of being buried in the ruines of Religion and Piety, as well as thy Civil Rights and Liberties; which are the two Ba≈øis, or Foundations on which thy temporary here, and future well-being hereafter con≈øi≈øts and ≈øtands. Ca≈øt thy Eye upon the Magi≈øtrates of the City of London (anciently ≈øtiled Caput regni & legum) in their Court of Iudicature at the Old-Bailey, and behold on the one hand Vertue termed Vice, Sobriety Debauchery, Religion Faction, Pious and Peaceable A≈ø≈øemblies Riots and Routs, and puni≈øhed as ≈øuch; On the other hand, the Ancient Written Laws denied, and their not written ones the Courts Authority: Iu≈øtice turned into Gaul, Right and Equity Quod non lego non credo Augu≈øt. by Will and Power over-ruled; ≈øo that its now become a Proverb, Tell me thy Judge, and I'll tell thee thy Law.

Said the learned Cook, Qui non libere veritatem pronunciat proditor veritas e≈øt; He who conceals Truth is a betrayer thereof. Therefore for the ≈øake of Truth, and the Readers benefit were the≈øe Proceedings made publick, and according to that due Ob≈øervation and impartial Account, which could be taken and collected of the manner of that Benches Arraigning and Condemning as well Religion, Piety,
Vertue and Sobriety, as Right, Equity, Liberty and Property, with due Comments upon their procedures from the Ancient and Fundamental Laws of this Land, are laid to thy view.

And had not the Mayor and Recorder, with the re≈øt of the Bench, prohibited many, by ≈øevere threats, from writing down the Courts partial Dealings both towards the Pri≈øoners and Iurors; and al≈øo by violence took away what others had adventured to collect (commanding ≈øome to their Bale-dock) in all probability this en≈øuing Piece might have been much more enlarged to thy ≈øatisfaction.

But what has been faithfully Collected and Ob≈øerved, and whereof there were ≈øome hundreds of Witne≈ø≈øes, is pre≈øented to the World, the Author (de≈øiring rather to ≈øpare their Inju≈øtice then wrong their Iudicature) has contracted this Relation to what comes within the limits of his own knowledge and undeniable proofs; but impartially laid Iudgment to the Line, and di≈øcovered that which may tend to the good of his Country men, in the Vindication of the Laws, Truth, Innocency Equity, and Iu≈øtice.

THe Laws of England, by Ju≈øt and upright Mini≈øters and Officers, faithfully di≈øpenced, and impartially admini≈øtred, have ever been the Upholders and Pre≈øervers of Right and Liberty, The high e≈øteemed & pretious Jewels of its freeborn Inhabitants: but when unlimited Prerogatives have ≈øpung up, like Mu≈øhromes out of the ≈øappy Apprehen≈øions, a≈øpiring Brains, and heady Humors of inferior Officers and Mini≈øters; Then Tyranny and Oppre≈ø≈øion have under di≈øgui≈øe of Ju≈øtice and colour of Law, deprived the Commonalty of the≈øe things, which they have held mo≈øt pretious and dear to them.

The pretended Crimes or Offences laid to the charge of Thomas Rudyard, are far different in their kind and nature from tho≈øe other Per≈øons, who have undergone with him the ≈øevere Judgments, or as ≈øome call them, the Inqui≈øitory like Cen≈øures of that Court, which were ≈øo far from Juris Dicta, The Law of Right or impartial di≈øpencing of Ju≈øtice, that they are clear contrary and directly oppo≈øit unto them: The Ju≈øtices of that Court, Judge Cook, that famous Engli≈øh Lawyer, doth well de≈øcribe in his 2d In≈øt. Fol. 55. in a Poetical Simile of an unju≈øt Judge.

This piece of practice was in open Court, which manife≈øts their partiallity and unequal dealings to ≈øuch whom they convened before them, to receive Ju≈øtice at their hands: And how little they (who ≈øate there as Judges) regarded their Oaths, and the duty of that place of ≈øo great a tru≈øt, is ea≈øily re≈øolved, weighing them in the Ballance of Law and Ju≈øtice, Said the learned Cook in his 3 In≈øt. fol. 29. Upon the 19th of the 4th Moneth, Francis Moor, Richard Mow, Richard Mayfeild, Richard knowlman, and Gilbert Hutton, with divers others of their Friends; being (as at other times) met together (to wait upon, and wor≈øhip the living God in Spirit and in Truth) at Whitehart-Court in Grace-Church-Street, London, (being forceably kept out of their own hou≈øe by Watch-men, and Con≈øtables) after they had there peaceably continued together, about the ≈øpace of one hour, the two Sheriffs of London, with their Guard of Officers and Souldiers, came in and made a Proclamation by one of their Servants, That all per≈øons there pre≈øent ≈øhould depart; which being not regarded by tho≈øe who peaceably came there, to give to God the things that were God's; they continued in peaceable manner together without di≈øtraction, not fearing what mans violence could do unto them, knowing that again≈øt the Innocent there was no Law: Yet the Sheriffs ≈øingled out of the A≈ø≈øembly the above ≈øaid Per≈øons (and delivering them into the cu≈øtody of one Whiting Beadle to the Bridgeward (who was a per≈øon very diligent in ≈øuch ≈øervices) and his Watchmen, who carryed them by the Sheriffs order to Bi≈øhop≈øgate-Goal; a place, who ever has had the Experience thereof, can witne≈øs its filthy noi≈øomne≈øs; and a horrid ≈øhame it is, that the Magi≈øtrates of this City ≈øhould make no better provi≈øion, then to incar≈øarate peaceable men, and their Fellow-Creatures, in places as it were on purpo≈øe to ≈øtifle or poi≈øon them, that they might be incapa≈ø≈øitated to make a due defence, again≈øt their intollerable and arbitrary Oppre≈ø≈øion.
